prompt: Facts: Incident occurred during the night between 11th and 12th May 1978, in Village Padli Gujran, District Alwar, Rajasthan.; The victim was Mst. Sua, wife of the respondent-accused, Narayan.; Narayan and Mst. Sua were sleeping alone inside their house, which was bolted from the inside.; Around midnight, neighbours (PW1 Girdhari, PW2 Harphool, PW3 Moolchand) heard cries emanating from Narayan's house.; Witnesses went to the house and found the door bolted from inside.; After some delay, Narayan opened the door.; Witnesses entered and found Mst. Sua lying dead on the ground with injuries on her neck.; Narayan initially claimed his wife had been bitten by a snake.; Narayan subsequently changed his statement, claiming some unknown intruders had entered the house and killed her.; Narayan himself had injuries on his hands and chin.; First Information Report (FIR) was lodged, and investigation commenced.; Post-mortem examination (by PW5 Dr. R. C. Gupta) revealed incised wounds on the neck, caused by a sharp weapon like a Kulhari (axe). Death was due to shock and hemorrhage resulting from these injuries, which were ante-mortem.; A Kulhari (axe) was recovered from Narayan's house at his instance (disclosure statement leading to recovery).; The recovered Kulhari and Narayan's clothes (dhoti and shirt) were found to be stained with human blood.; Serological report confirmed the blood on the Kulhari and Narayan's clothes was Group 'A'.; The blood group of the deceased, Mst. Sua, was also determined to be Group 'A'.; The Sessions Judge, Alwar, acquitted Narayan, disbelieving the witnesses and doubting the recovery evidence.; The High Court of Rajasthan upheld the acquittal, agreeing with the Sessions Court's assessment.; The State of Rajasthan filed an appeal against the acquittal in the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 300 (Murder - Definition, applied contextually), Section 106 Indian Evidence Act (Burden of proving fact especially within knowledge - invoked by SC)
